conclusion: The working principle of the electromagnetic railgun involves a projectile moving freely between two parallel rails, maintaining good contact with them. Current flows from one rail, through the conductive projectile, and back through the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile, which can be considered a uniform magnetic field. The electrified projectile is propelled at high speed along the rails due to the Lorentz force acting on it.

Xiao Ming purchased a railgun model online with a rail length of 0.5 m, a parallel rail spacing of 0.02 m, a projectile mass of 0.02 kg, a rail current of 10 A, and a magnetic field strength of 1 T. All resistances are neglected.
Lorentz force on the conductive projectile F = I d B = 10 A × 0.02 m × 1 T = 0.2 N
Acceleration of the projectile a = F / m = 0.2 N / 0.02 kg = 10 m s⁻²
Exit (launch) speed after travelling the 0.5 m rail v = √(2 a L) = √(2 × 10 m s⁻² × 0.5 m) = √10 ≈ 3.16 m s⁻¹
Instantaneous power at the muzzle (launch point) P = F v = 0.2 N × 3.16 m s⁻¹ ≈ 0.63 W
The railgun delivers about 0.6 W of power to the projectile at the instant it leaves the 0.5-m rails.
